misconceptions.name: Implemented a different program instead of the required grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a distance-between-points calculator rather than a grade-to-letter-grade converter, so the program never reads a single numeric grade 0–100, never uses conditional logic for grade ranges, and never outputs a letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that solving the distance-between-points problem is acceptable for this question, or confused this question with a different assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this task, the program should read one numeric grade (0–100) from the user, use if/else conditionals to check the grade against the specified ranges (A: 90–100, B: 80–89, etc.), and print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single numeric grade.
Program computes a Euclidean distance using Math.sqrt rather than evaluating grade ranges.
No conditional (if/else) statements are present to map numeric grades to letters.
Output describes the distance between two points instead of a letter grade like 'A', 'B', etc.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between assignment questions or reusing a previous solution without adapting it to the current specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Rewrite main to (1) prompt for and read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100, (2) use an if/else-if chain to test the grade against the A–F ranges, and (3) print the appropriate letter grade instead of a distance.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code never references grades or letter outputs and instead fully implements a distance calculation workflow, indicating a complete mismatch with the described grade-calculator task.

evidence.note: Program reads four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single numeric grade between 0 and 100.
Program computes and prints the distance between two points instead of using conditional logic to determine and print a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Solution Submitted
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for calculating the distance between two points instead of the required Grade Calculator program. None of the functionality required by the rubric (reading a grade, conditional logic for letter grades, or outputting a letter grade) is present.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student likely confused this submission with another assignment, submitting the solution for a 'Distance Between Points' problem when the 'Grade Calculator' was required.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional logic (if/else) to determine and output the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Code reads four coordinate values instead of one grade.
Code performs geometric calculation instead of conditional grading logic.
Output is a distance, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misplaced submission or fundamental misunderstanding of the required problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure the submitted code directly addresses the specific problem prompt. Review the file and class name to confirm they match the intended task (Grade Calculator).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code title and functionality (reading x1, y1, x2, y2, calculating distance) is 100% consistent with a different, known geometry task, and addresses none of the 'Grade Calculator' requirements.

evidence.note: The entire file implements a solution for calculating distance between points, using coordinates as input and the distance formula calculation, demonstrating a complete failure to address the Grade Calculator question.

misconceptions.name: Completely wrong problem solved
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for a different problem entirely (calculating distance between two points) instead of the assigned grade calculator problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code for a different assignment or copied code from another problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The student should have written a program that reads a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A/B/C/D/F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Code reads x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a numeric grade
Code calculates distance between points using distance formula
Output is completely unrelated to the assignment
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either submitted the wrong file, copied code from an unrelated problem, or misunderstood the assignment entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem specification carefully. Write code that: (1) reads a single integer grade, (2) uses if-else statements to check grade ranges, (3) outputs the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is objectively solving a completely different problem. There is no grade calculator logic whatsoever.

evidence.note: This is a distance calculator program, not a grade calculator. The entire logic is for a different problem.

misconceptions.name: Implemented a completely different problem (distance calculator instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute the distance between two points rather than a grade-to-letter-grade converter as specified. As a result, none of the rubric requirements (reading a single numeric grade, using conditional ranges for A–F, and outputting a letter grade) are addressed.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this task by writing a program that reads two points and computes the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade from 0 to 100 and use conditional logic to map it to a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) according to the given ranges, then print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade
No conditional statements (if/else) for grade ranges A–F
Output message reports distance between two points, not a letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation or disregard of the problem specification, leading to implementation of a different, unrelated problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and start from the required input and output: ask for one numeric grade, then use if/else if/else to check which range the grade falls into (90–100, 80–89, etc.) and print the corresponding letter grade.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric ranges to categories using conditionals
Designing input and output based on requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program structure and all prompts and calculations clearly correspond to a distance-between-points problem, with no trace of grade-related logic.

evidence.note: All input, computation, and output relate to calculating the distance between two points, with no grade input or letter-grade logic.

misconceptions.name: Solved wrong problem (Distance Calculation instead of Grade Calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating the distance between two points (a common introductory programming problem) instead of implementing the Grade Calculator required by the assignment (Q3).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student likely submitted code for a different assignment or misunderstood the required problem for Q3. They appear to believe that calculating the distance between two points fulfills the requirement.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task required reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional logic to output a letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Code reads four inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one (grade)
Code performs geometric calculation (distance formula) instead of grade conditional checks
Output message refers to distance, not letter grade
misconceptions.root_cause: Submission error or fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the assignment prompt for Q3. Delete the geometry calculation code and implement the logic for reading a single grade and mapping it to a letter grade based on the specified ranges (if/else if structure).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire provided code implements a completely different, unrelated problem (distance calculation), making it impossible to evaluate against any of the grade calculator rubric tasks.

evidence.note: The entire logic calculates distance between two points and does not attempt to solve the grade calculator problem (Q3).
